title: Software Engineering Midterm Exam
instructions: Covers Topics 1-4: SDLC, Requirements Engineering, Software Design/UML, and Design Patterns.
Answer all questions. Passing score is 70%.
For multiple choice, select the single best answer.

questions.prompt: Which SDLC model is characterized by sequential phases where each phase must be completed before the next begins?
questions.explanation: The Waterfall model follows a sequential approach where each phase (Requirements, Design, Implementation, Testing, Deployment, Maintenance) must be completed before moving to the next.

questions.prompt: What is the main advantage of iterative development?
options: Delivers working software incrementally with early feedback
questions.explanation: Iterative development delivers working software in increments, allowing for early feedback and course correction based on learning from each iteration.

questions.prompt: In the Spiral model, what is the primary focus of each iteration?
questions.explanation: The Spiral model is risk-driven, with each iteration focusing on identifying and mitigating the highest risks before proceeding to the next phase.

questions.prompt: What does DevOps primarily aim to achieve?
options: Integrate development and operations for faster, more reliable delivery
Eliminate the need for version control
Reduce the number of developers needed
questions.explanation: DevOps integrates development and operations through automation and collaboration, enabling faster and more reliable software delivery.

questions.prompt: Which project characteristic makes Waterfall a poor choice?
questions.explanation: Waterfall is poorly suited for projects with rapidly changing or unclear requirements because it is rigid and changes are expensive once a phase is complete.

questions.prompt: What is the V-Model's key characteristic?
options: Each development phase is paired with a corresponding testing phase
questions.explanation: The V-Model pairs each development phase with a corresponding testing phase, ensuring verification and validation at each level.

questions.prompt: What is technical debt?
options: The future cost of rework from choosing quick solutions over better approaches
questions.explanation: Technical debt represents the implied future cost of rework needed when we choose quick or expedient solutions now instead of better approaches that take longer.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a functional requirement?
options: The system shall respond within 2 seconds
The system shall allow users to create an account
The system shall support 1000 concurrent users
The system shall be available 99.9% of the time
questions.explanation: Functional requirements describe what the system should do. "Allow users to create an account" describes a specific function. The others are non-functional (performance, scalability, reliability).

questions.prompt: What is a non-functional requirement?
options: A requirement about what the system does
A requirement about how well the system performs (quality attributes)
A requirement that cannot be tested
questions.explanation: Non-functional requirements specify quality attributes like performance, security, usability, reliability, and maintainability - how well the system performs its functions.

questions.prompt: Which elicitation technique involves observing users in their natural work environment?
questions.explanation: Ethnography involves observing and studying users in their natural work environment to understand their actual practices, context, and needs.

questions.prompt: A well-formed user story follows which template?
questions.explanation: User stories follow the template "As a [role], I want [feature], so that [benefit]" to capture who wants what and why.

questions.prompt: What does INVEST stand for in user stories?
options: Independent, Necessary, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable
Integrated, Negotiable, Verified, Executable, Simple, Testable
Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable
Independent, Notable, Valid, Essential, Specific, Timely
questions.explanation: INVEST stands for Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, and Testable - qualities of good user stories.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between verification and validation?
options: Verification is for developers; validation is for users
Verification: "Did we build it right?"; Validation: "Did we build the right thing?"
questions.explanation: Verification checks if the product meets specifications (built right), while validation checks if it meets user needs (built the right thing).

questions.prompt: What is requirements traceability?
options: The ability to trace requirements from origin through implementation and testing
questions.explanation: Requirements traceability links requirements to their sources and tracks them through design, implementation, and testing phases.

questions.prompt: What does the Single Responsibility Principle state?
options: A class should have only one method
A class should inherit from only one parent
A class should have only one instance
A class should have only one reason to change
questions.explanation: The Single Responsibility Principle states that a class should have only one reason to change, meaning it should have only one job or responsibility.

questions.prompt: What is the Open/Closed Principle?
options: Classes should be open for modification, closed for extension
Classes should be open for extension, closed for modification
Classes should have both getters and setters
questions.explanation: The Open/Closed Principle states that software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification - you can extend behavior without changing existing code.

questions.prompt: What does high cohesion mean?
options: Elements within a module are strongly related and focused on a single purpose
questions.explanation: High cohesion means elements within a module are strongly related and focused on a single, well-defined purpose, improving maintainability.

questions.prompt: What does loose coupling mean?
options: Classes have minimal dependencies on other classes
All classes are in one package
Classes are highly dependent on each other
questions.explanation: Loose coupling means classes have minimal dependencies on other classes, making the system more flexible and easier to modify.

questions.prompt: In UML class diagrams, what does a solid line with a filled diamond represent?
questions.explanation: A solid line with a filled diamond represents composition - a strong "whole-part" relationship where the part cannot exist independently of the whole.

questions.prompt: What does a UML sequence diagram show?
options: Object interactions over time through message exchanges
questions.explanation: UML sequence diagrams show how objects interact with each other over time through message exchanges in a particular scenario or use case.

questions.prompt: Which architectural style organizes a system into horizontal layers with specific responsibilities?
questions.explanation: Layered architecture organizes a system into horizontal layers (e.g., presentation, business logic, data access) where each layer has specific responsibilities.

questions.prompt: Which category of design patterns deals with object creation?
questions.explanation: Creational patterns deal with object creation mechanisms, providing flexible ways to create objects while hiding creation logic.

questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of the Singleton pattern?
options: To ensure a class has exactly one instance with global access
questions.explanation: The Singleton pattern ensures a class has only one instance and provides a global access point, useful for resources like configuration managers or connection pools.

questions.prompt: What does the Factory Method pattern do?
options: Defines an interface for creating objects, letting subclasses decide which class to instantiate
questions.explanation: The Factory Method pattern defines an interface for creating objects but lets subclasses decide which class to instantiate, promoting loose coupling.

questions.prompt: What problem does the Observer pattern solve?
options: Defining a one-to-many dependency so observers are notified when subject changes
questions.explanation: The Observer pattern defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so when one (the subject) changes state, all its dependents (observers) are notified automatically.

questions.prompt: What is an anti-pattern?
options: A pattern that improves code quality
A common but ineffective solution that creates more problems
questions.explanation: An anti-pattern is a common response to a recurring problem that is usually ineffective and risks being counterproductive, creating more problems than it solves.

questions.prompt: The Adapter pattern is used to:
options: Convert an interface into another interface that clients expect
questions.explanation: The Adapter pattern converts an interface of a class into another interface that clients expect, allowing incompatible interfaces to work together.

title: Software Engineering Final Exam
instructions: Comprehensive exam covering all topics: SDLC, Requirements, Design/UML, Patterns, Testing, Version Control/CI/CD, and Agile.
Answer all questions. Passing score is 70%.
For multiple choice, select the single best answer.

questions.prompt: Which SDLC model is best for projects with well-defined, stable requirements?
questions.explanation: Waterfall works best when requirements are well-defined and stable, allowing for comprehensive upfront planning and sequential execution.

questions.prompt: What is the main benefit of the Spiral model?
options: Risk-driven approach with iterative risk assessment
questions.explanation: The Spiral model's key benefit is its risk-driven approach, identifying and mitigating risks in each iteration before proceeding.

questions.prompt: Which is a functional requirement?
options: Users can export data to CSV format
questions.explanation: Functional requirements describe what the system does. Exporting to CSV is a function. The others are non-functional (performance, availability, scalability).

questions.prompt: What makes a good user story according to INVEST?
options: It should be Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, and Testable
It should be written by developers only
questions.explanation: INVEST is a mnemonic for good user story qualities: Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, and Testable.

questions.prompt: What does requirements validation ensure?
options: Requirements correctly capture stakeholder needs and are feasible
questions.explanation: Validation ensures that requirements correctly capture what stakeholders actually need and that those requirements are feasible to implement.

questions.prompt: The Single Responsibility Principle promotes:
options: Each class having one reason to change
questions.explanation: SRP states each class should have one reason to change, meaning one responsibility or job, improving cohesion and maintainability.

questions.prompt: In UML, a dashed arrow represents:
questions.explanation: A dashed arrow in UML represents a dependency relationship, indicating one class uses or depends on another.

questions.prompt: MVC (Model-View-Controller) separates:
questions.explanation: MVC separates applications into Model (data), View (presentation/UI), and Controller (control logic), promoting separation of concerns.

questions.prompt: Which pattern category does Observer belong to?
questions.explanation: Observer is a behavioral pattern that defines how objects communicate and interact, specifically implementing a publish-subscribe mechanism.

questions.prompt: The Strategy pattern allows:
options: Defining a family of interchangeable algorithms
questions.explanation: The Strategy pattern defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable, allowing the algorithm to vary independently.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between verification and validation in testing?
options: Verification: built it right; Validation: built the right thing
Verification is automated; validation is manual
questions.explanation: Verification checks if we built the product right (meets specs), while validation checks if we built the right product (meets user needs).

questions.prompt: Which testing level tests individual units in isolation?
questions.explanation: Unit testing tests individual units or components in isolation to verify they work correctly independently of other components.

questions.prompt: What is black-box testing?
options: Testing with knowledge of internal code
Testing based on specifications without knowledge of implementation
questions.explanation: Black-box testing tests functionality based on specifications without knowledge of internal implementation, focusing on inputs and expected outputs.

questions.prompt: What is white-box testing?
options: Testing with knowledge of internal code structure
questions.explanation: White-box testing examines internal code structure and logic, designing tests to exercise specific paths, branches, and conditions.

questions.prompt: In Test-Driven Development (TDD), when do you write tests?
questions.explanation: In TDD, tests are written before production code. The cycle is Red (write failing test), Green (make it pass), Refactor (improve code).

questions.prompt: What is the TDD cycle called?
questions.explanation: The TDD cycle is "Red-Green-Refactor": Red (write failing test), Green (make it pass), Refactor (improve while keeping tests green).

questions.prompt: The test pyramid suggests:
options: Many unit tests, fewer integration tests, even fewer UI tests
Equal numbers of all test types
questions.explanation: The test pyramid advocates for many fast unit tests at the base, fewer integration tests in the middle, and fewer slow UI/end-to-end tests at the top.

questions.prompt: What does code coverage measure?
options: The percentage of code executed by tests
questions.explanation: Code coverage measures the percentage of code (lines, branches, statements) that is executed when the test suite runs.

questions.prompt: Does 100% code coverage guarantee bug-free software?
options: No, coverage does not guarantee all behaviors are correctly tested
questions.explanation: 100% coverage does not guarantee correctness. Tests might execute code but not verify all behaviors, edge cases, or business logic correctness.

questions.prompt: What is a mock object?
options: A simulated object that mimics real objects for testing
questions.explanation: A mock object simulates the behavior of real objects, used to isolate the unit under test from its dependencies.

questions.prompt: What is regression testing?
options: Re-running tests to ensure existing functionality still works after changes
questions.explanation: Regression testing re-runs tests to ensure existing functionality still works after code changes, catching unintended side effects.

questions.prompt: What is the primary purpose of version control?
options: To track changes over time and enable collaboration
questions.explanation: Version control tracks changes to code over time, enabling collaboration, maintaining history, and allowing reversion to previous versions.

questions.prompt: What is a commit in version control?
options: A snapshot of changes saved to the repository with a descriptive message
questions.explanation: A commit is a snapshot of changes saved to the repository with a message describing what changed and why, creating a point in history.

questions.prompt: What is a branch in version control?
questions.explanation: A branch is an independent line of development, allowing work on features or fixes without affecting the main codebase.

questions.prompt: What does "git clone" do?
options: Creates a local copy of a remote repository
questions.explanation: "git clone" creates a local copy of a remote repository, including all files, branches, and commit history.

questions.prompt: What is a pull request?
options: A request to merge changes from one branch to another for review
questions.explanation: A pull request (or merge request) is a request to merge changes from one branch into another, enabling code review and discussion.

questions.prompt: What is trunk-based development?
options: Frequent integration of small changes into a single main branch
questions.explanation: Trunk-based development has developers integrate small changes frequently into a single main branch, with short-lived feature branches if any.

questions.prompt: What is a merge conflict?
options: When Git cannot automatically merge due to overlapping changes
questions.explanation: A merge conflict occurs when Git cannot automatically merge changes because the same lines were modified differently in the branches being merged.

questions.prompt: What is Continuous Integration (CI)?
options: Automatically building and testing code on every commit
questions.explanation: CI automatically builds and tests code whenever changes are committed, providing rapid feedback on integration issues.

questions.prompt: What is Continuous Deployment (CD)?
options: Automatically deploying every change that passes tests to production
questions.explanation: Continuous Deployment automatically deploys every change that passes automated tests to production without manual intervention.

questions.prompt: What differentiates Continuous Delivery from Continuous Deployment?
options: Delivery requires manual approval for production; Deployment is automatic
questions.explanation: Continuous Delivery means code is always deployable but requires manual approval for production. Continuous Deployment is fully automatic to production.

questions.prompt: What is a CI/CD pipeline?
options: An automated sequence of build, test, and deploy stages
questions.explanation: A CI/CD pipeline is an automated sequence of stages (build, test, deploy) that code changes pass through, ensuring quality and enabling rapid delivery.

questions.prompt: Which Agile Manifesto value is correct?
options: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Following a plan over responding to change
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto values "Individuals and interactions over processes and tools," along with working software, customer collaboration, and responding to change.

questions.prompt: What is a sprint in Scrum?
options: A time-boxed iteration (1-4 weeks) to complete planned work
questions.explanation: A sprint is a time-boxed iteration in Scrum, typically 1-4 weeks, during which the team completes a set of planned work items.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the daily standup?
options: A brief sync meeting to share progress and identify obstacles
questions.explanation: The daily standup is a brief meeting where team members synchronize work, share progress, and identify obstacles blocking progress.

questions.prompt: What is the Product Owner's role in Scrum?
options: Defining and prioritizing the product backlog
questions.explanation: The Product Owner defines and prioritizes the product backlog, represents stakeholders, and ensures the team delivers maximum value.

questions.prompt: What happens in a retrospective?
options: The team reflects on the process and identifies improvements
questions.explanation: A retrospective is a meeting where the team reflects on what went well, what didn't, and how to improve their process.

questions.prompt: What does Kanban emphasize?
options: Visualizing work and limiting work in progress (WIP)
questions.explanation: Kanban emphasizes visualizing work flow (on a board) and limiting work in progress to improve flow and reduce bottlenecks.

questions.prompt: What are WIP limits in Kanban?
options: Maximum number of items in progress at any stage
questions.explanation: WIP (Work In Progress) limits restrict the maximum number of items in progress at any stage, helping identify bottlenecks and improve flow.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of code reviews?
options: To improve quality, share knowledge, and catch defects early
questions.explanation: Code reviews improve code quality, facilitate knowledge sharing, catch defects early, and ensure consistency with standards.

questions.prompt: What is refactoring?
options: Restructuring code to improve design without changing behavior
questions.explanation: Refactoring restructures existing code to improve its internal structure and design without changing its external behavior.

questions.prompt: What is technical debt?
options: The future cost of rework from choosing quick solutions over better approaches
questions.explanation: Technical debt represents the implied future cost of rework needed when choosing quick solutions now instead of better approaches that take longer.

questions.prompt: What is a code smell?
options: An indicator in code suggesting a deeper problem
questions.explanation: A code smell is a surface indication in code that suggests a deeper problem, such as duplicated code, long methods, or excessive complexity.
